text: being a gay player in NFL from 1964 to
1973 it was a really tough time in the
locker room there was all kinds of
homophobic remarks and it was it was a
dark ages it's it's been the dark ages
in there for a long time
for me I was dealing with my sexuality
people didn't understand there wasn't
the the talk of gay people all over the
news or in television or anything there
was nothing when I went to Washington
there was a player Jerry Smith who had
much more experience than I did with
life he embraced me and I grew to love
Jerry I grew to love him as a person
because he was so supportive and so
loving Jerry Smith and Dave co-pay
weren't the only gay ball players in the
National Football League there's been
players of unbelievable success and
recognition recognition that might be
the highest recognition in all of sports
that are gay or closeted
when I heard that this young man was an
all-american co-defensive Player of the
Year I wanted to go over to visit him I
kind of punched him up and I kind of
said you know you got a well you got to
bring it like you never brought it
before I says all this talk about your
sexuality is there's a place for it and
it's now it'll be for a few days and
it'll be over with but you got to go to
training and you got to make the team
and and you can make the team is the
locker room gonna be any different now
than it was when I played well it sure
as hell is gonna be different because
look at the way Michael Sams own
teammates purported themselves when he
told all of the teammates and including
the coach that he was gay they stuck up
for him they they didn't want to reveal
it there's that issue themselves to
other people he they wanted to give him
the right to speak out according to when
he chose to speak out when he felt good
and comfortable and ready to speak out
any and and he did that would never have
happened in my day you know
you
